summary: This is an email chain from February 1, 2021, discussing the production of the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report on the Jeffrey Epstein case to defense counsel. The emails note the report is publicly available and coordinate language to avoid accusing Congress of leaking it, instead stating it is publicly available. Links to the report on various news sites are provided.

events.title: OPR Report Becomes Publicly Available
events.description: The full DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility report on the Jeffrey Epstein case investigation became publicly available.

events.title: Email Coordination on OPR Report Production
events.description: Prosecutors coordinate via email on producing a copy of the publicly available OPR report to defense counsel, discussing cover letter language.

keyFacts: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) produced a full report on the Jeffrey Epstein case investigation.
The full OPR report was publicly available by November 2020, not just an executive summary.
The report was provided to Congress, which released it, leading OPR to request that correspondence not affirmatively accuse Congress of leaking it.
The email chain includes links to the report hosted by The New York Times, The Washington Post, DocumentCloud, and Scribd.
Prosecutors planned to produce the report to defense counsel as a courtesy, noting its public availability to avoid claims of sandbagging.
